lines.text: Listen, Sue, you and I are going to have a little talk. There never was anything to be afraid of that can't be cured by one little word. Do you know what that word is? Courage. It can beat the toughest situation that ever happened. You see, when you're afraid of things, the more you think of them, the bigger they get. But if you just throw your head back and say, 'I won't be scared of anything anymore,' then you're not.
Aren't you ever afraid of anything?

Well, let's put it this way. Whenever I meet up with something I'm not quite sure of, I decide first thing that everything's going to be all right. Whatever it is, I'm going to lick it. And usually, it does come out all right.
This is Miss Susannah Sheldon.
Just call me Sue.
Now, young lady, we'll have to arrange sleeping quarters for you.
Where would that be, sir?
Your room.
What?
Am I to sleep with him?
Oh, no. Pat can sleep out here on the couch.
But I wouldn't want to take Mr. Pat's room.
Oh, that's all right. Pat'll be very comfortable, won't you, Pat?
Oh, yes, sir.
Pat, you old pirate! Why didn't you tell me to change uniforms? Why, she's a beauty!
Tell you? I did tell you!
You didn't tell me anything of the kind! That's just the kind of thing you should tell me! When did she get here? You didn't even tell me she was young!
Two days ago.
And I had to be out on patrol. Why, she's beautiful. She's pretty as a picture! You didn't even tell me she had blue eyes! And deep blues eyes at that!
Dad didn't think I should come, even for a visit.
You must find it rather rugged.
I've been wondering...
What?
Well, whatever was it that made a man like you take a job like this?
There are times when it's rather hum-drum, but right now you're here.
And I'm going to change things. Inspector Montague, we're going to give a dance next Wednesday night. A real one. Dress uniform and frills.
A dance?
You do dance, don't you?
Well, I - yes, yes, of course.
Splendid. Being the only woman in the vicinity, I'm bound to be popular.
Anything serious, Dad?
Just a little Indian trouble at my camp.
Nothing for you to worry about.
This is hardly the best time for you to have come out here, Vicky, but I can't tell you how glad I am to see you.
Don't tell me I leave you speechless, Harlan.
You always did.
What are you making?
Never you mind, now. Curiosity killed a cat, you know.
You shouldn't be sewing. That's a woman's work.
Not in the army, doll. That's where I learned it.
You men on the force should have wives to do things for you.
I pity the poor girl that would marry a man in this outfit.
Why?
They're a no-good lot of heartbreakers, they are.
Are you the chief Indian?
Me Big Eagle.

Well, I certainly hope Mr. Standing makes you Indians behave this time! And if you got what you deserve, he'd send you all to jail! That's where you belong for what you've been doing! What gives you the right to ...
Here, here, Sue. You'll have to forgive her, Big Eagle. This little girl was the only survivor of the wagon train.
Golden Hawk, little spirit of the sun, Big Eagle sorry you have trouble. Will not happen again.
I don't see why you want to fight the white people anyway. They haven't done anything to hurt you.
You're a wonderful rider.
Squaw ride?
Well, I ...
Unh.
Oh, you think I'm afraid, do you? Come on, help me on. Well, aren't you going to help me?
Brave never help squaw.
You're not very polite, are you?
Unh.
Mr. Monty says I'm much more grown-up than you are and I should try to understand you. So, we'll smoke the pipe of peace.
What? Squaw smoke?
Well, I never have, but we're going to make a peace treaty, and you have to smoke on that, don't you?
Unh.
I guess that means yes.
Unh.
Why don't you say yes when you mean yes and no when you mean no?
You look very nice.
Thank you, Sue.
How do you think I look?
You look very nice, too. Where did you get that dress?
Mr. Pat bought it for me.
Well, well, good for Pat.
Thank you, sir.
It'd be a nice dress to go to a party in.
You'd be the belle of the ball.
If I was invited to a party.
What are you doing? Give me that!
But it's only a piece of old buffalo skin I've been using to polish Mr. Monty's boots.
Why, Sue, that's Mr. Pat's pride and joy. It's his toupee!
Toupee?
Sure. Show her, Pat.
Yes, sir.
No, no, no, put it on.
Oh, it's your hair! I'm awfully sorry! I didn't know! You look so handsome you'd think you'd want to wear it all the time.
Oh, yes, he's a real lady-killer with that on.

[singing]
I'll teach you to waltz!
This is the music I learned to waltz to. I can remember it just as if it had been tonight.
Why squaw not asleep?
I guess if everyone else can stay up dancing, I can stay up and watch them.
Redcoat make her his squaw?
He will not!
Funny he dance like that and not make her his squaw.
He's only doing that to be nice to her.
Indian dance better. Use feathers.
Ooh, let me try it on!
No! Only brave wear feathers!
Well, I've got one, anyway. Where did you get all these things?
Warrior bring. Bring teepee, too. Little Chief no sleep white man's house.
You could sleep anywhere, if you were tired enough.
Unh.
With all this attention, I'm beginning to appreciate the advantages of being a pioneer woman.
It's fun while it lasts, Vicky, but you won't like it once the going gets rough.
I'd like you to be there when I went home for the holidays.
Well, Harlan, I may have other plans. I might decide to become a pioneer woman at that. Don't you think I could, Inspector Montague?
Do what?
Don't you think I could become a pioneer woman?
I'm sure you could, if you put your mind to it.
Well, Harlan, that's one vote for me.
Maybe someday you'll teach me an Indian dance.
Unh.
Isn't he rude? These Indians certainly are a problem.
You don't seem to have much trouble handling Little Chief.
It took time for me to understand him, though, but it was worth it.
Really?
Yes, because I expect to be here for a long time. But it wouldn't be worthwhile for you to go to all that trouble, because you're going home soon.
Am I?
Aren't you? Mr. Pat said you were, and I expect you wouldn't like it out here anyway, because it's full of ...
Sue, that's enough. Goodnight, now.
Goodnight.
You'll have to forgive her, Vicky. She's a somewhat strange child.
He's in love with her!
Aye, me doll, 'tis one of the delightful misfortunes that overtakes the male of the species. 'Tis me that knows.
I wish she'd go back where she came from!
Oh, you're jealous, you are.
I am not! But she couldn't take care of him the way we do! I'll bet she couldn't even make his bed! And you're not doing it right, either!
Oh, I'm not, ain't I?
You haven't the covers up close enough for around his neck. And you should unfold his nightshirt and have it all laid out for him.
What are you trying to do, spoil him? Here, give me that!
Oh, Mr. Pat, and I taught him how to dance with her!
Oh, Mr. Monty, I'm so glad you're back. I've been so worried.
You shouldn't be up this late, Sue.
But I had to tell you. Little Chief says the Indians are going to kill all the white men and redcoats, because of what happened at the railroad camp.
Railroad camp?
What happened, Sue?

The Indians tried to sell Mr. Chambers his own horses back, and Mr. Chambers got so mad, because the Indians were trying to cheat him, he said he was going to bring soldiers out to make them behave. The Indians didn't like that, and when they tried to leave, the woodmen pulled them off their horses and started hitting them!
I've been trying to reach Big Eagle and tell him he has nothing to fear from Chambers's threats.
I'm afraid it's too late for talk now.
What is it, Father? Trouble?
Yes, plenty, and our friend Chambers started it.
Now squaw put out finger.
And let you cut it? I will not!
Squaw afraid?
No! Oh, you did cut it! It's bleeding!
Now put together. Make Golden Hawk and Little Chief blood brothers.
You mean this will make me an Indian?
Unh. Indian now.
Oh, is my face turning red?
No, stay paleface.
I'm glad of that.
Here some more ammunition, Mr. Pat.
Thank you, doll. Now get down, get down. No, get behind me.
Oh, Mr. Pat, I've looked everywhere, and no one seems to know what's become of Mr. Monty.
Never you mind, now. You've had no rest all night. Sit down, and as soon as I've finished this, I'll get you a bit of breakfast.
Oh, I couldn't eat! I better keep looking!
Are you all right, sir?
Aye, lassie, it's just a wee nip of me hand.
Have you seen Mr. Monty?
Well, I can't say that I have.
He isn't in the hospital with the wounded men, and he isn't around the garden or the stables. I've looked everywhere!
Oh, dinna worry your head, lassie. Mr. Monty can take care of himself under any circumstances.
I was taken prisoner while on patrol, sir, and held up in Big Eagle's camp. Just before dawn this morning, Inspector Montague was brought in. I was released to give you a message.
Go on.
Big Eagle demands that the railroad leave his territory within the next two days, or Inspector Montague will not be released and the hostilities will be reopened.
What are you going to do, Father? You must send some word.
There's only one answer to such a demand. Refusal.
Iron horse not go away, you die.
The iron horse won't go away, Little Chief, not for me or anyone else.
Chief Redcoat big fool. All white men die.
If they do, many more will come, and that will be bad medicine for the Indians.
Big talk. Indians kill them, too. I get cold water for sick head.
Thanks. That would be a help.
Do it for Golden Hawk. She friend. Too bad you die. Make her feel sorry.
Sue!
Oh, Mr. Monty, have they hurt you?
I'm all right. How did you get here?
I came to see Mr. Big Eagle. Mr. Standing sent to another post for help, but they can't get here in time, so after dark tonight, he's coming with some men to try to rescue you.
Looks to me as if Big Eagle is showing his defiance. He knows the dispensing of justice belongs to the mounted police.
I'll bring it up when he comes to sign the peace treaty.
If it's ever signed.
Chambers, if I should decide to send Vicky home, could you do anything for me in way of transportation?
Why, I certainly could, sir.
Oh, Mr. Monty, if they try to do anything to you, they'll have to kill me, too!
